Although, now that I think about it, you even have composibility in C with structs, but you wouldn't call that "object orientation" :smile:

Also, since you mentioned inheritance, the Go language (although it does have OO features) does not use inheritance but composition. You don't take a simple type and extend it into a similar type that does other things additionally (sometimes this causes you to have to override the original functionality of the simple type), instead you make several useful atomic types and combine them into bigger types.

@levlas you mentioned anti-patterns. Java is a very OO culture and Java developers LOVE patterns. I recently read an article (probably about the Go language) which mentioned that the need for patterns points to a flaw in the language, that the language has so many ways of achieving the same thing that it is complicated and difficult to use, so we have to invent extra rules (Patterns) to make it easier to do things right. One of the main ideas behind the Go language was to make it so simple that there is a single obvious way to do things, making the code easier to read and making it harder to make mistakes or waste time deciding which "Pattern" fits the problem best.
